occurrences.line_text: There dead on ground. What doe ye then deuise
Where when they saw their foes dead out of doubt,
Like one of those two Knights, which dead there lay.
That earst was dead, restor'd to life againe,
Wayting his foe, it did her dead hart cheare,
Earst chawd thereon, yet was not all so dead,
He would her succour, and aliue or dead
She deem'd him sure to haue bene dead on ground,
To rayse a lyuing blame against the dead:
Giuen to me the spoile of this dead knight,
But Tristram then despoyling that dead knight
Vpon the steed of her owne late dead knight:
He her not finding, both them thus nigh dead did leaue.
Where I had surely long ere this bene dead,
Came forth in hast: where when as with the dead
But still did lie as dead, and quake, and quiuer,
For th'one is dead, and th'other soone shall die,
He weened well, that he in deed was dead,
Who though she were with wearinesse nigh dead,
Being alreadie dead with fearefull fright.
Then Coridon woxe frollicke, that earst seemed dead.
Tho when as he was dead, the fray gan ceasse,
This dismall day, and was not dead before,
That better were with them to haue bene dead,
Or if that dead, how he her death might wreake,
Were dead, right so as Coridon had taught:
In dead of night, when all the theeues did rest
Was almost dead, misdoubting least of new
Through the dead carcases he made his way;
That long had lyen dead, and made againe aliue.
And art thou yet aliue, whom dead I long did faine.
Which hauing thought long dead, she fyndes aliue,
Hold, ï¿½ deare Lord, hold your dead-doing hand,
Gan fade, and liuely spirits deaded quight:
Therewith the cowheard deaded with affright,
His hart quite deaded was with anguish great,
That was to him on earth the deadliest despight.
How to take life from that dead-liuing swaine,
Lay now thy deadly Heben bow apart,
For light she hated as the deadly bale,
That welnigh choked with the deadly stinke,
Groning full deadly, all with troublous feare,
Where when all drownd in deadly sleepe he findes,
That euer to haue toucht her, I did deadly rew.
And dimmed sight with pale and deadly hew
And that dread Lyons looke her cast in deadly hew.
And all in deadly sleepe did drowned lie,
To taste th'vntryed dint of deadly steele;
With thrilling point of deadly yron brand,
And each to deadly shame would driue his foe:
The creeping deadly cold away did shake:
Couering your foe with cloud of deadly night,
Where griesly Night, with visage deadly sad,
Lo where the stout Sansioy doth sleepe in deadly shade.
But he was wary of that deadly stowre,
And saw the signes, that deadly tydings spake,
That doe this deadly spectacle behold,
But seeled vp with death, shall haue their deadly meed.
Thrise did she sinke adowne in deadly swownd,
That deadly dint of steele endanger may:
Mine onely foe, mine onely deadly dread,
Hurles forth his thundring dart with deadly food,
Dismaied with so desperate deadly wound,
Which loue had launched with his deadly darts,
For leuer had I die, then see his deadly face.
Lookt deadly dull, and stared as astound;
Both deadly sharpe, that sharpest steele exceeden farre.
And found no place his deadly point to rest.
The deadly dint his dulled senses all dismaid.
And deadly woundes could heale, and reare againe
Durst not approch, for he was deadly made,
When the last deadly smoke aloft did steeme,
In sea of deadly daungers was distrest;
He could escape fowle death or deadly paines?
And deadly food he makes: him to offend
With that a deadly shrieke she forth did throw,
Pittifull spectacle of deadly smart,
So well he did her deadly wounds repaire,
As one out of a deadly dreame affright,
Then casting vp a deadly looke, full low,
That through the great contagion direfull deadly stunck.
Each other does enuie with deadly hate,
With deadly rancour he enraunged fond,
Their deadly cruell discord to forbeare,
Had wrought, and many whelmd in deadly paine,
And towards gan a deadly shaft aduaunce,
Or earthly wight thou be, withhold this deadly howre.
Those deadly tooles, which in her hand she held,
And drew his deadly weapon, to maintain his part.
Of deadly drugs I gaue him drinke anon,
And deadly sharpe he held, whose heads were dight
But did him deadly daunt, or fowle dismay;
Deadly dismayd, with horrour of that dint
That deadly daunger, soone atweene them ran;
Both yeeld, to stay your deadly strife a space.
And dolefull sorrow heape with deadly harmes:
To see my Lord so deadly damnifyde
His deadly wounds within my liuers swell,
But direfull deadly blacke both leafe and bloom,
In those sad waues, which direfull deadly stanke,
All which he did, to doe him deadly fall
And all his senses were with deadly fit opprest.
Whiles deadly fit thy pupill doth dismay;
And deadly hew, an armed corse did lye,
Hath him befalne, but cloudes of deadly night
And wisely watch to ward that deadly stowre:
Which oft the Paynim sau'd from deadly stowre.
All deadly daungerous, all cruell keene,
Discharged of his bow and deadly quar'le,
Into most deadly daunger and distressed plight.
But soone as they approcht with deadly threat,
Deadly engored of a great wild Bore,
Was drowned in the depth of deadly sleepe,
Drew out a deadly bow and arrow keene,
Whiles thus he lay in deadly stonishment,
This was that woman, this that deadly wound,
Soone as she vp out of her deadly fit
The lucklesse Marinell, lying in deadly swound;
Cursed the hand, that did so deadly smight
So deepe the deadly feare of that foule swaine
Of deadly daunger, which to him betid;
A cruell shaft, headed with deadly ill,
That from his steed he fell in deadly swowne;
With bloud deformed, lay in deadly swownd:
How him in deadly case their Lady fownd,
Which with his cruell tuske him deadly cloyd:
And with fell looke and hollow deadly gaze
Him selfe from deadly daunger to defend:
He from that deadly throw made no defence,
By Sanglamort my sword, whose deadly dent
Whilest deadly torments do her chast brest rend,
Quite through transfixed with a deadly dart,
When her from deadly thraldome he redeemed,
Through mischieuous debate, and deadly feood,
And deadly points at eithers breast to bend,
That did not seeke t'appease their deadly hate,
Where it was ment, (so deadly it was ment)
Till feeling life to fayle, it fell, and deadly slept.
Him selfe to saue from that so deadly throw;
And pacifie the strife, which causd so deadly smart.
And deadly foes so faithfully affrended,
So dreadfull were his strokes, so deadly was his hond.
And snatching forth his direfull deadly blade,
Where byting deepe, so deadly it imprest,
His hart was thrild with point of deadly feare;
The arrow, to his deadly marke desynde,
The burden of the deadly brunt did beare
For since the day that first with deadly wound
He ment the thiefe there deadly to haue smit:
Or else what other deadly dismall day
He to her lept with deadly dreadfull looke,
Into the riuer, where he drunke his deadly last.
Which when the Damzell, who those deadly ends
That with most fell despight and deadly hate,
Working to all, that loue her, deadly woe,
That deadly daunger seem'd in all mens sight,
Wrapt in great dolours and in deadly feares,
There did the Prince him leaue in deadly swound,
And powred forth his wretched life in deadly dreare.
Full deadly wounds, where so it is empight;
Could euer loose, but suffred deadly doole.
That him nigh choked with the deadly stinke:
And new life to her lent, in midst of deadly feare.
Of great defence to ward the deadly feare,
His deadly weapon, which in hand he held.
Right in the flanke him strooke with deadly dreare,
That of the deadly swound, in which full deepe
Like one that out of deadly dreame awooke:
In dolorous dismay and deadly plight,
Whom now in deadly daunger he did see;
Which had them freed from that deadly feare,
And in three battailes did so deadly daunt,
Or by some deadly chaunce be done to pine,
Kept, and deliuered me from deadly dread.
Whom when the Prince so deadly saw dismayd,
That other swayne, like ashes deadly pale,
Her heart does quake, and deadly pallid hew
Her wretched life, shut vp in deadly shade,
Of highest Ioue, who doth true iustice deale
To mens subiection, did true Iustice deale:
With that his wife in friendly wise to deale,
His studie was true Iustice how to deale,
For ye haue much adoe to deale withall.
What time king Ryence raign'd, and dealed right,
That both to good and bad he dealeth right,
Artegall dealeth right betwixt
Which vnto them was dealing righteous doome.
Dealing iust iudgements, that mote not be broken
Dealing of Iustice with indifferent grace,
Dealing his dreadfull blowes with large dispence,
Whole to commit, and to his dealing iust.
So fierce he laid about him, and dealt blowes
But stoutly dealt his blowes, and euery way
Of which he dealt large almes, as did befall:
And dealt her blowes vnmercifully sore:
All is his iustly, that all freely dealth:
Yt nought too deare I deemd, while so my dear I sought.
He loued Isse for his dear est Dame,
Conceiued had, to see her owne dear knight,
The deare remembrance of his dying Lord,
Her scattred brood, soone as their Parent deare
Ah my deare Sonne (quoth he) how should, alas,
Your owne deare sake forst me at first to leaue
Loue of your selfe, she said, and deare constraint
He would not shend, but said, Deare dame I rew,
For all so deare as life is to my hart,
With bowres, and beds, and Ladies deare delight:
And said, Deare dame, your suddein ouerthrow
And to this wretched Lady, my deare loue,
O too deare loue, loue bought with death too deare.
O too deare loue, loue bought with death too deare.
That moues more deare compassion of mind,
For the late losse of her deare loued knight,
That blind old woman and her daughter deare
Then forth they ranne like two amazed deare,
That should as death vnto my deare hart light:
Deare Sir, what euer that thou be in place:
In choice, and change of thy deare loued Dame,
Yet he of Ladies oft was loued deare,
Ah deare Sans ioy, next dearest to Sans foy,
Of deare Sansfoy, I neuer ioyed howre,
Thy selfe thy message doe to german deare,
Why suffredst thou thy Nephewes deare to fall
That whylome was to me too dearely deare.
And said, Deare daughter rightly may I rew
And yet more sad, that Vna his deare dreed
Her children deare, whom he away had wonne:
But her deare heart with anguish did torment,
Aye me, Deare dame (quoth he) well may I rew
From that day forth Duessa was his deare,
For whose deare sake so many troubles her did tosse.
Ah Ladie deare, quoth then the gentle knight,
Whose parents deare, whilest equall destinies
That Parents deare from tyrants powre deliuer might.
And of my dolefull disauenturous deare:
Faire virgin to redeeme her deare
Therefore, deare Sir, your mightie powres assay.
That when his deare Duessa heard, and saw
Of pitty deare his hart was thrilled sore,
This dayes ensample hath this lesson deare
Deare Dame (quoth he) you sleeping sparkes awake,
She to me made, and bad me loue her deare,
For Gods deare loue, Sir knight, do me not stay;
Now praysd, hereafter deare thou shalt repent:
Then Vna thus; But she your sister deare;
The deare Charissa where is she become?
Then said the aged Coelia, Deare dame,
His owne deare Vna hearing euermore
Of that deare Lord, who oft thereon was fownd,
More deare vnto their God, then you[n]glings to their dam.
To thinke of those her captiue Parents deare,
Deare knight, as deare, as euer knight was deare,
Deare knight, as deare, as euer knight was deare,
Deare knight, as deare, as euer knight was deare,
The brasen towre in which my parents deare
But yet more mindfull of his honour deare,
And daintie deare, which on the ground still fell,
Of her deare knight, who wearie of long fight,
And his deare Ladie, that beheld it all,
Then when his daughter deare he does behold,
Deare Sonne, great beene the euils, which ye bore
The fairest Vn' his onely daughter deare,
Ne wonder; for her owne deare loued knight,
And to the knight his daughter deare he tyde,
His deare delights were able to annoy:
Deare Lady how shall I declare thy cace,
The stricke[n] Deare doth chalenge by the bleeding wound.
For Gods deare loue be not so wilfull bent,
Ah deare Sir Guyon, well becommeth you,
And that deare Crosse vpon your shield deuizd,
Ay me, deare Lady, which the image art
Speake, O deare Lady speake: help neuer comes too late.
Ah farre be it (said he) Deare dame fro mee,
My Lord my loue; my deare Lord, my deare loue,
My Lord my loue; my deare Lord, my deare loue,
Hard helpe at need. So deare thee babe I bought,
Yt nought too deare I deemd, while so my dear I sought.
Her deare besought, to let her dye a mayd.
And by the loues, which were to them most deare,
Be therefore, O my deare Lords, pacifide,
She Guyon deare besought of curtesie,
Hold, ï¿½ deare Lord, hold your dead-doing hand,
Did court the handmayd of my Lady deare,
That I may more delight in thy embracement deare.
And said, Deare sonne, thy causelesse ruth represse,
Made drunke with drugs of deare voluptuous receipt.
On him, that did Pyrrochles deare dismay:
Whom should he, but his owne deare Lord, there see,
His owne deare Lord Pyrrochles, in sad plight,
And euery pillour decked was full deare
Do flocke about, my deare my daughter is;
Of his deare safetie, I to thee commend;
His life for due reuenge should deare abie?
And his deare hart the picture gan adore,
And said, Deare sir, whom wandring to and fro
My liefe, my liege, my Soueraigne, my deare,
But both her selfe, and eke her daughter deare,
But wanting issew male, his daughter deare
Cryde out, Deare countrey, Ã´ how dearely deare
Cryde out, Deare countrey, Ã´ how dearely deare
Which now him turnd to disauantage deare;
Which seeing good Sir Guyon, deare besought
For whose deare sake full many a bitter stownd,
In the deare closet of her painefull side,
Ah my deare daughter, ah my dearest dread,
Of my deare foster child, to ease thy griefe,
And her faire deawy eies with kisses deare
O daughter deare (said she) despaire no whit;
But thine my Deare (welfare thy heart my deare)
But thine my Deare (welfare thy heart my deare)
And sore reproch, when so her father deare
This my deare daughters deepe engraffed ill,
Proud of his dying honor and deare bands,
The God did graunt his daughters deare demaund,
And all that else was pretious and deare,
Tryde often to the scath of many deare,
Her deare sonnes destinie to her to tell,
Which when his mother deare did vnderstond,
She made so piteous mone and deare wayment,
Deare image of my selfe (she said) that is,
That so deepe wound through these deare members driue.
The guilt I doe ascribe: deare wisedome bought too late.
That the dim eyes of my deare Marinell
Of my deare Dame is loued dearely well;
She found, and brought it to her patient deare
Mercy deare Lord (said he) what grace is this,
More deare then life she tendered, whose flowre
The losse of her deare brood, her deare delight:
The losse of her deare brood, her deare delight:
Her deare Adonis ioyous company,
Who wandring for to seeke her louer deare,
Her louer deare, her dearest Marinell,
Villein (said he) this Ladie is my deare,
Like as the rest, late entrance deare besought;
That madest many Ladies deare lament
For nothing may impresse so deare constraint,
Accomplished, that many deare complaind:
And eke Sir Paridell, all were he deare;
It was that Ollyphant, the brother deare
Ne worldly price cannot redeeme my deare,
So louedst thou the faire Coronis deare:
Both for those two, and for his owne deare sonne,
Ne ought but deare Bisaltis ay could make him glad.
He loued eke Iphimedia deare,
His owne deare mother, (ah why should he so?)
Her heauy eyes with natures burdein deare,
Or that same daintie lad, which was so deare
As a dismayed Deare in chace embost,
Who her deare nourslings losse no lesse did mourne,
Like as a Deare, that greedily embayes
Now the sweet lodge of loue and deare delight:
And magnifying louers deare debate;
The deare compassion of whose bitter fit
Through cruell knife that her deare heart did kerue.
Some of deare louers, foes perpetuall:
He had small lust to buy his loue so deare,
Yet thou false Squire his fault shalt deare aby,
Full many knights, that loued her like deare,
And those two Ladies their two louers deare,
And robd the world of threasure endlesse deare,
And loue each other deare, what euer them befell.
First to her brother, whom she loued deare,
By all that vnto them was deare, did them beseeke.
Dame Venus girdle, by her steemed deare,
And as her life by her esteemed deare.
The face of his deare Canacee vnheale;
The which ere long full deare he shall abie.
Then her besought, as she to her was deare,
Ne euer was there wight to me more deare
For she deare Ladie all the way was dead,
Streight into griefe, that her deare hart nigh swelt,
A leman fit for such a louer deare.
His owne deare Lord Prince Arthure came that way,
That albeit his owne deare Squire he were,
With deare compassion deeply did emmoue,
And eke his deare companion of his care.
And eke all mindlesse of his owne deare Lord
That lou'd me deare, as dearest thing aliue.
That her deare hart full deepely made to rew,
She deare besought the Prince of remedie:
The deare affection vnto kindred sweet,
Her owne deare sire, she cald to him for aide.
Which was the captiue Squire she lou'd so deare,
For losse of his deare loue by Neptune hent,
And vsury withall: such gaine was gotten deare.
Such were great Hercules, and Hylas deare;
Was forst to seeke my lifes deare patronesse:
The noursling of Dame Memorie his deare,
And of my lifes deare loue beloued be:
For his deare sake, that ill deseru'd that plight:
For her, but for his owne deare Ladies sake,
With all deare delices and rare delights,
And gaue them gifts and things of deare delight.
Ah my deare dread (said then the faithfull Mayd)
But on their mother Earths deare lap did lie,
Of thy sires Crowne, and from thy countrey deare.
Vnto the man, whom thou doest loue so deare;
Ah my deare Lord, what sight is this (quoth she)
From which like mazed deare, dismayfully they flew.
Of Bacchus Priests her owne deare flesh did teare.
Nathlesse (said he) deare Ladie with me goe,
That downe he fell vppon his mother deare,
With her two sonnes, right deare of her beloued,
Saying; Deare Lady, deedes ought not be scand
His deare Redeemers badge vpon the bosse:
Is ought on earth so pretious or deare,
For fayre Irena, whom they loued deare.
In Faery court, but him did deare embrace,
She long time hath deare lou'd a doughty Knight,
With a faire Damzell, my beloued deare,
Abett, perhaps he mote it deare aby.
And him adoring as her liues deare Lord,
For deare affection and vnfayned zeale,
Conuay to be recur'd. She thankt him deare,
Was inly touched with compassion deare,
And deare affection of so dolefull dreare,
But sigh't and sorrow'd for her louer deare,
The fearefull Lady to her father deare,
Vnlesse thou dare for thy deare Ladies sake,
To draw him from his deare beloued dame,
His deare affect with silence did restraine,
Or deare aby, for why his Lord of old
Had doen to him, and his deare Ladie shent:
That for his sake his deare life had forgone;
And first they spoile her of her iewels deare,
For her did languish, and his deare life spend;
I from thenceforth haue learn'd to loue more deare
Thus to bereaue thy Loues deare sight from thee:
His Loues deare spoile, in which his heart was prayde,
To make it seeme more deare and dainty, as is meet.
To make the prises of the rest more deare.
Then backe returning to his dearest deare,
In bloudy battell for a Ladie deare,
Is her owne daughter, her owne infant deare.
That brothers hand shall dearely well requight
That whylome was to me too dearely deare.
A gentle youth, his dearely loued Squire
For dearely sure her loue was to me bent,
Him dearely kist, and fairely eke besought
And Ladies loue to leaue so dearely bought?
Her dearely doth imbrace, and kisseth manifold.
Else be ye sure he dearely shall abyde,
But vaine: for ye shall dearely do him rew,
There thou maist loue, and dearely loued bee,
That after soone I dearely did lament:
I cast to pay, that I so dearely bought;
Which to auenge on him they dearely vowd,
That direfull stroke thou dearely shalt aby.
That sacked Rome too dearely did assay,
Cryde out, Deare countrey, Ã´ how dearely deare
Her Sea-god syre she dearely did perswade,
Of my deare Dame is loued dearely well;
The Gods doe dread, he dearely shall abye:
For her he dearely loued, and in all
I sweare, ere long shall dearely it repent;
Whence dearely she with death bought her desire.
I did assay, that me right dearely cost,
These three did loue each other dearely well,
That made them dearely lou'd of each degree;
My Sire, who me too dearely well did loue,
Nathlesse his pride full dearely he did pryse;
To haue him slaine, or dearely doen aby.
I yearned haue, that life so dearely did redeeme.
When his foote slipt (that slip he dearely rewd,)
The fruite of ioy and blisse, though long time dearely bought.
It dearely shall aby, and death for handsell pay.
These eyes saw die, and dearely did lament:
Was neuer Ladie loued dearer day,
Nathlesse her honor dearer then her life,
Much dearer be the things, which come through hard distresse.
Dearer is loue then life, and fame then gold;
But dearer then the[m] both, your faith once plighted hold.
His life he steemed dearer then his frend.
The which to heare, vouchsafe, O dearest dred a-while.
My dearest Lord fell from high honours staire,
He thereto meeting said, My dearest Dame,
Ah dearest Dame, (quoth then the Paynim bold,)
His dearest loue the faire Fidessa loe
Ah deare Sans ioy, next dearest to Sans foy,
His ancient loue, and dearest Cyparisse,
Ah dearest Lord (quoth she) how might that bee,
Ah dearest dame (quoth he) how might I see
My dearest Lord, and deepe in dongeon lay,
She said, Ah dearest Lord, what euill starre
When him his dearest Vna did behold,
Ah dearest God me graunt, I dead be not defould.
Ah dearest Lord, said then that doughty knight,
On gallow trees, in honour of his dearest Dame.
His dearest Dame is that Enchaunteresse,
To the faire Critias his dearest Belamy.
Offring his seruice, and his dearest life
Ah my deare daughter, ah my dearest dread,
And choseth vertue for his dearest Dame,
Begin then, ï¿½ my dearest sacred Dame,
Should of his dearest daughters hard misfortune heare.
Her dearest sonne, her dearest harts delight.
Her dearest sonne, her dearest harts delight.
Dayes dearest children be the blessed seed,
Ah dearest God (quoth he) that is great woe,
That she her dearest sonne Cupido sought,
